Name: Mathematics in 10 Lessons: The Grand Tour

ReviewList.Text: Mathematics in 10 Lessons: The Grand Tour deserves ongoing recommendation as a powerful guide to math for any outside the usual field. Its ten lessons are intended for the general reader who wants to know how math is done, but has little prior math knowledge. A lively format and explanations make for a readable survey of basic math principles and aesthetics perfect for those who would appreciate an easy, lively overview. Any general lending library will want this.
The Kindle version is fatally flawed, orthographically. One example: "n" is used in the same sentence to represent  both the number n and the square root of n.

I have this in book form and I love it. It is an excellent step by step introduction to the basic principles of mathematics. I would give it five stars, but recently, while rereading it. I decided to get the Kindle version so I could read it on my tablet. That was a mistake. The equations are in the form of graphics so small as to be nearly unreadable. I am very disappointed.
This is the best math book ever
"Mathematics in 10 Lessons" is on the ROROTOKO list of cutting-edge intellectual nonfiction. Professor King's book interview ran here as cover feature on June 3, 2009.
